fields.value: ABC News O.J. Simpson and the Media Poll, July 1994

dsDescriptionValue.value:
This special topic poll, conducted by ABC News during July   1994, attempted to gauge opinion on the natio
nally televised O.J.   Simpson trial. Respondents were also asked if they thought the   country was going in the right direction or off track. Questions   regarding the O.J. Simpson trial included how closely the respondents   had been following the trial, whether they had seen the preliminary   court hearing, how they would rate the media's coverage of the case,   and if there was too much coverage of the case. Respondents were   asked to speculate on coverage of the Simpson case and if the   coverage had effected coverage of other stories, like domestic abuse.   Respondents were asked whether they believed that Simpson would   receive a fair trial, what they believed the verdict would be, and   whether they believed he should get the death penalty if convicted.   Background information includes level of education, age, ethnicity,  and sex.

topicClassValue.value: ICPSR XIV.C.1. Mass Political Behavior and Attitudes, Public Opinion on Political Matters, United States

fields.value: Version Date: 2007-05-07Version Text: 2007-05-07Version Date: 2007-05-07Version Text: 2007-05-07 Subject: null  Type: null  Notes: SAS, SPSS, and Stata setup files have  been added to this data collection.; Subject: null  Type: null  Notes: Card Image with SAS, SPSS, and Stata setup files;Subject: Study Level Error Note, Notes: (1) Additional information about sampling,   interviewing, weighting, and sampling error may be found in the   codebook. (2) This collection has not been processed by ICPSR staff.   ICPSR is distributing the data and documentation for this collection   in essentially the same form in which they were received. When   appropriate, documentation has been converted to Portable Document   Format (PDF), data files have been converted to non-platform-specific   formats, and variables have been recoded to ensure respondents'   anonymity. (3) The codebook is provided by ICPSR as a Portable   Document Format (PDF) file. The PDF file format was developed by   Adobe Systems Incorporated and can be accessed using PDF reader   software, such as the Adobe Acrobat Reader. Information on how to   obtain a copy of the Acrobat Reader is provided on the ICPSR Web  site.; Subject: null  Type: null  Notes: Data file(s), and electronic documentation.;

distributorName.value: Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research

distributorAffiliation.value: Institute for Social Research, University of Michigan

value: Persons aged 18 and over living in households with  telephones in the contiguous 48 United States.

fields.value: Households were selected by random-digit dialing. Within   households, the respondent selected was the adult living in the   household who last had a birthday and who was home at the time of the  interview.
